t: How*pn beautiful are your sandaled feet, princess! The*ln curves of your thighs are like jewelry, the*ln handiwork of a master.
Your*ln navel is a rounded bowl; it*ln never lacks mixed wine. Your*ln belly is a mound of wheat surrounded*ln by lilies.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, twins*ln of a gazelle.
Your*ln neck is like a tower of ivory, your*ln eyes like pools in Heshbon by*ln Bath-rabbim’s gate. Your*ln nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking*ln toward Damascus.
Your*ln head crowns you like Mount Carmel, the*ln hair of your head like purple cloth — a*ln king could be held captive in your tresses.
How*ln beautiful you are and how pleasant, my*ln love, with such delights!
Your*ln stature is like a palm tree; your*ln breasts are clusters of fruit.
I*ln said, “I will climb the palm tree and*ln take hold of its fruit.” May*ln your breasts be like clusters of grapes, and*ln the fragrance of your breath like apricots.
Your*ln mouth is like fine wine—
flowing*pn smoothly for my love, gliding*ln past my lips and teeth!
I*ln am my love’s, and*ln his desire is for me.
Come,*pn my love, let’s*ln go to the field; let’s*ln spend the night among the henna blossoms.
Let’s*ln go early to the vineyards; let’s*ln see if the vine has budded, if*ln the blossom has opened, if*ln the pomegranates are in bloom. There*ln I will give you my caresses.
The*ln mandrakes give off a fragrance, and*ln at our doors is every delicacy, both*ln new and old. I*ln have treasured them up for you, my love.
